item.title: Texas Flood Deaths Rise as Rescuers Pursue Grid Search
item.description: At least 67 people have died and dozens of children are missing in the Texas Hill Country after catastrophic flooding that left officials struggling to explain whether they did enough to warn people of the fast-rising waters.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger, Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: Onlookers survey damage caused along the Guadalupe River after a flash flood swept through Kerrville, Texas, on Friday, July 4, 2025,

item.title: Ship Catches Fire After Coming Under Attack Near Yemeni Port
item.description: Multiple small vessels hit an unidentified ship in the Red Sea near Yemen’s Al Hudaydah port, the UK Maritime Trade Operations said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Sara Gharaibeh

media:content.media:description: AL HUDAYDAH PORT, YEMEN -- JULY 2, 2024: Maxar closeup satellite imagery of the Yemeni port city of Al Hudaydah before the reported Israeli airstrikes . Please use: Satellite image (c) 2024 Maxar Technologies. Photographer: Maxar/Maxar

item.title: Lula and Modi Take Center Stage as BRICS Begins With Xi Absent
item.description: Unlike Brazil’s Group of 20 summit, no one was late or missing when leaders of the world’s major emerging-market nations gathered for a family photo Sunday in Rio de Janeiro — at least not accidentally.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy, Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: BRICS leaders pose for a family photo at the BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro on July 6.

item.title: Mexico Keeps Up Oil and Fuel Shipments to Crisis-Stricken Cuba
item.description: Mexico’s state-owned oil company is throwing Cuba a much-needed lifeline as the Caribbean island struggles to keep its power grid operational amid its worst economic crisis since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Wicary

media:content.media:description: A residents walks in the street during a power outage in Havana on June 26, 2025. Photographer: Yamil Lage/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: US Trade Partners Chase Deals as Bessent Eyes Busy 72 Hours
item.description: Major US trading partners hurried over the weekend to secure trade deals or lobby for extra time as President Donald Trump said he’s notifying about a dozen countries on Monday of the new tariff level on their shipments to the US.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: Trucks carrying shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California, US, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. US President Donald Trump exempted Canadian goods covered by the North American trade agreement known as USMCA from his 25% tariffs, offering major reprieves to the US's two largest trading partners.

item.title: Thailand to Offer US More Trade Concessions to Avert 36% Tariff
item.description: Thailand is making a last-ditch effort to avert a punitive 36% export levy threatened by the Trump administration with offers of greater market access for US farm and industrial goods, along with increased purchases of energy and Boeing jets.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes next to shipping containers at the Bangkok Port in Bangkok, Thailand, Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024. Thailand is scheduled to announce export figures on Jan. 31.

item.title: Troubled Israel-Hamas Talks Will Bedevil Trump’s Bid to End War
item.description: US President Donald Trump hopes to put Israel and Hamas on the path to ending the war in Gaza this week, but the 60-day ceasefire he’s proposing faces disagreements over troop redeployments and civilian relief.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Israeli demonstrators demanding a ceasefire in Gaza and the release of Israeli captives in Tel Aviv, Israel, on July 5.

item.title: French Companies Seek to Invest $947 Million in Malaysia
item.description: Several French companies seek to invest a total of 4 billion ringgit ($947 million) in Malaysia after a trade delegation led by Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim met with 40 industry representatives in France on Friday, according to Malaysia’s Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: A Rapid KL train travels along an elevated track in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on Sunday, Jan. 14. 2024. Malaysia is scheduled to release it's annual gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Jan. 19. Photographer: Richard Humphries/Bloomberg

item.title: China Retaliates Against EU on Medical-Device Procurement
item.description: China will impose some reciprocal curbs on medical-device procurement for companies based in the European Union, adding tensions between the two major trading partners just as Beijing seeks to shore up ties while it fights a trade war with the US.
item.dc:creator: Wenshan Luo, Ying Tian

media:content.media:description: hospital medical equipment heart monitor vital statistics (photos professionally retouched - Photoshop action added) Photographer: eyecrave/Getty Images

item.title: Odd Lots: Eating Steak With Taleb and McElligott (Podcast)
item.description: Author Nassim Nicholas Taleb and Nomura strategist Charlie McElligott are well-known for their opinions on things like trading, risk and uncertainty. But they also have very strong opinions on food! Nassim famously talks a lot about squid ink pasta, for instance, while Charlie is a well-known meat lover. So we thought we’d invite them to a special meal, one that would be recorded live onstage at our recent event in New York. This is a special subscriber-only bonus episode of our live steak-eatin
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Kosovo Fails Again to Elect Speaker After Bomb Threat: Koha.net
item.description: Kosovo’s lawmakers failed once again to elect a speaker of parliament during a session on Saturday evening, which was delayed earlier in the day due to a bomb threat that forced the evacuation of the parliament building in the capital, Pristina, according to Koha.net.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Kuzmanovic

media:content.media:description: Members of Kosovo's parliament in Pristina. Photographer: Armend Nimani/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Khamenei Makes First Public Appearance Since Israel-Iran War Started
item.description: Iran’ s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei on Saturday made his first public appearance since the 12-day war between Israel and Iran began, attending a mourning ceremony on the eve of Ashoura.

media:content.media:description: Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei attends an Ashura ceremony in Tehran, Iran, in this photo released by the Iranian Leader Press Office on July 6, 2025.

item.title: Israel Will Send Mediators to Talks Aimed at Gaza Ceasefire
item.description: Israel will send mediators on Sunday to restart talks with Hamas, after the militant group said it was ready to “immediately” negotiate a proposal by US President Donald Trump for a 60-day ceasefire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams, Ethan Bronner, Fares Alghoul

media:content.media:description: This picture taken from a position at Israel's border with the Gaza Strip shows smoke billowing during an Israeli strike on the besieged Palestinian territory on July 3, 2025, amid the ongoing war between Israel and the Hamas Islamist militant group. (Photo by Menahem Kahana / AFP) (Photo by MENAHEM KAHANA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Musk Declares ‘America Party’ Formed After Trump’s Bill Passes
item.description: Elon Musk said a new political party he has been threatening to start up “is formed,” a day after President Donald Trump signed a tax-cut and spending bill that the Tesla Inc. billionaire chief executive officer has denounced.
item.dc:creator: Sam Kim (News)

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., walks on the South Lawn of the White House after arriving on Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, March 9, 2025. US President Donald Trump said Sunday he was negotiating with four different possible buyers for TikTok’s US business and that a deal for the social video app could come “soon.”

item.title: Colombia Arrests Key Suspect in Senator Assassination Attempt
item.description: Colombian police arrested one of the main suspects in the June assassination attempt of Senator Miguel Uribe Turbay, Caracol Radio reported.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Colombia's Police Director Carlos Triana stands in front of a projected image of Elder Jose Arteaga Hernandez (alias 'El Costeño'), allegedly responsible for the attack on Colombian presidential candidate Miguel Uribe, during a press conference in Bogota on July 5, 2025.

item.title: France Urges Tariff Barriers to Stop China From Killing Industry
item.description: French Finance Minister Eric Lombard said Europe must shore up its tariff barriers to counter Chinese imports that risk harming the continent’s industrial economy.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: A steel storage warehouse in Hangzhou, China, on Friday, Feb. 7, 2025. Metals investors are weighing the prospect of worsening international trading conditions after the Trump administration slapped tariffs on China and threatened other countries including Canada and Mexico.

item.title: Protesters Supporting Banned Palestine Action Arrested in UK
item.description: LONDON (AP) — More than 20 people were arrested Saturday on suspicion of terrorism offenses after protesters gathered in central London in support of Palestine Action.

media:content.media:description: Metropolitan Police officers observe a protest in support of Palestine Action, organised by the Defend Our Juries group, in front of the Mahatma Gandhii statue in Parliament Square, central London, on Saturday July 5, 2025.

item.title: UK Re-Establishes Syria Ties Eight Months After Fall of Assad
item.description: UK Foreign Secretary David Lammy traveled to Damascus to renew diplomatic relations with Syria on Saturday, eight months after the overthrow of former President Bashar Al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Angela Cullen

media:content.media:description: People celebrate in Damascus' Omeyyad square after US President Donald Trump's decision to lift sanctions in Syria, on May 13, 2025.

item.title: BRICS Set to Condemn Trade-Distorting Tariffs in Swipe at Trump
item.description: BRICS leaders are poised to adopt a position at odds with President Donald Trump on trade tariffs, conflict in the Middle East and global arms spending, even as they shy away from any direct challenge to the US.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Signage for the BRICS summit 2025 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on July 4.

item.title: Farage Ally Resigns From Reform UK Over Business Probe
item.description: A Reform UK lawmaker has temporarily stepped back following a report of alleged business impropriety by companies he owned during the pandemic, marking a setback for the right-wing insurgent party led by Nigel Farage.
item.dc:creator: Angela Cullen

media:content.media:description: James McMurdock Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Gabon Leader Unveils Political Party, State Broadcaster Reports
item.description: Gabon’s leader Brice Oligui Nguema officially unveiled a new political party as the oil-producing OPEC member prepares for parliamentary and local government elections, Gabon 24 reported.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Brice Oligui Nguema is draped with a Gabon flag while celebrating his presidential election at his campaign headquarters in Libreville on April 13.

item.title: Japan Top Trade Negotiator Holds Two Phone Meetings With Lutnick
item.description: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa held two phone meetings with US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to discuss tariffs as a July 9 deadline for higher levies nears.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa, Japan's economic revitalization minster, speaks to members of the media at the Japanese embassy in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 6, 2025. Japan and the US have begun the latest round of trade negotiations, with media reports suggesting Tokyo’s delegation is trying to win a reprieve from the tariffs by pledging to make more cars in the US and enhancing cooperation on rare earths.

item.title: Turkey Detains Three Mayors in Widening Probe, Anadolu Reports
item.description: Turkish police detained the mayors of three cities and a number of other officials, the state-run Anadolu Agency reported, in an escalation of a probe into municipalities governed by the opposition Republican People’s Party, or CHP.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: A Turkish national flag, left, and a flag bearing the portrait of Kemal Ataturk, founder of the modern Turkish republic, hang from the exterior of a building in the Sisli district of Istanbul, Turkey, on Monday, Aug. 29, 2022. Turkey’s central bank delivered a shock cut to interest rates despite inflation soaring to a 24-year high and the lira trading near a record low. Photographer: Nicole Tung/Bloomberg

item.title: Spanish PM Sanchez Announces Party Reshuffle Amid Graft Probe
item.description: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez vowed to “defeat corruption in and out” as he announced a reshuffle within Socialist Party ranks — even as an ally was forced to resign over sexual harassment allegations.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: (From L) PSOE President Cristina Narbona, Spain's Prime minister Pedro Sanchez and Spain's deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Budget Maria Jesus Montero attend a Socialist federal committee at Spain's Socialist party (PSOE) headquarters in Madrid on July 5.

item.title: Ghost Factories Are a Warning Sign for Green Manufacturing’s Future
item.description: Rollbacks of clean-energy credits in Trump’s tax bill add to the sector’s challenges as project cancellations rise.
item.dc:creator: Saijel Kishan

media:content.media:description: A plot of land for sale where Kore Power’s project had previously been announced.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US Jobs Data Eases Pressure on Fed
item.description: Fresh US jobs figures took pressure off the Federal Reserve to consider an interest-rate cut later this month, likely leaving the central bank on hold at least until the fall.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: Recruiters and job seekers speak during a job fair hosted by the Cook County government to support federal workers in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Thousands of private government consultants laid off during the Trump administration's cost-cutting crusade are increasingly flooding a shrinking labor market.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Strikes Air Base in Russia’s Voronezh Region
item.description: Ukraine’s military said its special forces struck the Borysoglebsk airfield in Russia’s Voronezh region as Kyiv continues to look for ways to reduce the Kremlin’s ability to conduct airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

item.title: BlackRock Halted Ukraine Fund Talks After Trump’s Election Win
item.description: BlackRock Inc. halted its search for investors to back a multibillion-dollar Ukraine recovery fund earlier this year after Donald Trump’s election victory saw the US sour on the eastern European country, people familiar with the discussions said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Donato Paolo Mancini, Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Women walk dog as smoke rises over Kyiv following mass Russian drones and missile strikes on the Ukraine's capital on July 4, 2025. Photographer: Oleksii Filippov/AFP

item.title: Starmer Has Nowhere to Go, Stuck Between Rebels and Bond Market
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is caught between a political rebellion and a jittery bond market.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Philip Aldrick, Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, right, and Rachel Reeves in London on July 3. Photographer: Jack Hill/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Death Count Climbs in Texas After Severe Flooding
item.description: KERRVILLE, Texas (AP) — Months worth of heavy rain fell in a matter of hours on Texas Hill Country, leaving 24 people dead and many more unaccounted for Friday, including more than 20 girls attending a summer camp, as search teams conducted boat and helicopter rescues in fast-moving floodwaters.

media:content.media:description: Fallen trees and debris in the Guadalupe River in Kerrville, Texas, on July 4. Photographer: Eric Gay/AP Photo
